The intersection of Greenwich Street, and West Broadway, at Vesey Street. Shown is Greenwich Street, (Ninth Ave., Elevated) east side, north from Vesey, to, but not including Barclay Streets.

May 5, 1927.

P. L. Sperr.

The same location, showing Christmas trees piled outside of these retail gardener shops for sale to Jersey commuters.

December 11, 1937.

P. L. Sperr.

Battery Park and its surrounding office structures as viewed northward from the waters edge.  Broadway is thru the center where the dominant Standard Oil Building appears.  This overlooks the Washington, Custom House and Cheseborough buildings.  In the background are the Irving Trust, Equitable Trust, Bank of Manhattan and the City Bank Farmers Trust buildings.  Note the old Elevated Line winding its way around the park to enter Greenwich Street.

October 1928
August 1929
February 1931

George L. Balgue
title: Manhattan: Battery Park.

text:
(1)
Vesey Street, north side, east from (No. 52) but not including West
Broadway, showing a portion of the Sixth Ave. Elevated Line on Church
Street and across it the 18-story Underwood Building at the N.E. corner
of Church Street. The row of buildings from No. 52 to 32, at the N.W.
corner of Church Street (where elevated structure is seen), is part of
the block which was razed to be replaced by a United States Post Office
in 1935.
July 26, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
A detail of the same, from a different angle, showing only Nos. 48
to 54. (These houses are seen in view 1, in the left foreground, in  their reverse order).
July 26, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

(1)
64 to 60 Vesey street, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of West Broadway, showing only the lower parts of buildings concerned. The entire block of which these were a part have been demolished; and upon this site has been erected a U. S. Post Office.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A view of the store front of No. 58.
P. L. Sperr.
July 26, 1930.

West Broadway, east side, north from Vesey to Barclay Streets, showing the buildings that stood on the present (1937) site of the United States Post Office. Also shown (right) are buildings on Vesey Street, at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner.

July 25, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) West Broadway, east side, north from but not including Vesey, to and including Murray Streets. July 26, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, showing a further view to the South. July 26, 1930.

P. L. Sperr.

(3) The same, still further southward, to and including Vesey Street. Also shown is Vesey Street, at and adjoining the N.E. corner of West Broadway. July 29, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

West Broadway, from Vesey (right) to Park (left) Streets, showing the United States Post Office site prior to clearance. This new structure will occupy an entire block, bounded by West Broadway east to Church Street and Vesey north to Barclay Streets. The blocks to the north of same (left) are still the property of Columbia University. View No. 2 shows the P.O. site and the block to the south, with Greenwich Street for a westerly boundary and Fulton Street on the south. The "El" in the foreground is on the former while across the top appears the Sixth Avenue line on Church Street. The photographers vantage point is the Telephone Building from which he is viewing eastward.

August 6, 1930
Views 1 and 2

P.L. Sperr

(3)

An additional view in a more northward direction to include a view to Murray Street where the Sixth Avenue "El" makes a bend eastward towards Church Street. This photograph emphasizes the Columbia property; same being the 2 center blocks and the 3 small block units in the foreground between Greenwich Street and West Broadway.

August 6, 1930
View 3.

P.L. Sperr

(1)
Vesey Street, north side, east from but not inoluding West Broadway, to Church Street, showing a site for the U. S. Post office being prepared. Aoross the background, from left to right, appears the Woolworth, Transportation and Underwood Buildings. Note in View 2 the 6th Avenue Elevated
Line on Church Street.
August 2, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same at a later date, showing demolition in a more advanced s tage.
September 28, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.

West Broadway, west side, north from Vesey, to, but not including Barclay Streets, as seen from Vesey and Church Streets, from the excavation for the United States Post Office.

November 25, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Church Street, at the N.W. corner of Vesey Street. Also shown is Vesey Street, north side, west from Church, to Greenwich Streets. The view shows the new downtown Post Office in process of construction. Note the Sixth Ave., Elevated across the top of view.

August 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from an altitude, and showing West Broadway (across clearance) west side, north from Vesey, to and including Barclay Streets. Note the Ninth Ave., Elevated structure on Greenwich Street.

March 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(1) Church Street, at the N.W. corner of Vesey Street. Also shown is Vesey Street, north side, west from Church, to Greenwich Streets. The view shows the new downtown Post Office in process of construction. Note the Sixth Ave., Elevated across the top of view.

August 21, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from an altitude, and showing West Broadway (across clearance) west side, north from Vesey, to and including Barclay Streets. Note the Ninth Ave., Elevated structure on Greenwich Street.

March 27, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
